hawaiian_text: 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ua 'ike au, he kanaka nui nō 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, a ua hele aku nei ma Ko'olau, a 'o wau he inoa nona." 'Ī mai lākou: "'A'ole, 'o 'oe nō, pela ko makou lohe, no laila, e make ana 'oe iā mākou, 'a'ole 'oe e ola." 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ho'i aku ho'i hā kākou i lalo e hakakā ai." A hiki lākou i lalo, e hao aku ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, pau loa i ka make, a koe aku ho'okahi kanaka, 'o ia ka i holo aku ā loa'a 'o 'Ama'u ma Waikīkī, 'ōlelo akula ia i ka make o lākou a pau loa, a koe ia i 'āha'ilono e lohe ai 'o 'Ama'u.
deepseek-v3-0324-fireworks_translation: Nāmakaokapāo'o declared: "I have seen that Nāmakaokapāo'o is indeed a great man, and he has gone to Ko'olau, and I bear his name." They replied: "No, it is you indeed, thus we have heard, therefore you shall die by our hands, you shall not live." Nāmakaokapāo'o responded: "Let us all go down and fight." When they descended, Nāmakaokapāo'o violently overpowered them until all were dead, except one man who fled and reached 'Ama'u at Waikīkī. He reported the death of all their companions, leaving only him to deliver the news for 'Ama'u to hear.
deepseek-v3-0324-fireworks_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>
Nāmakaokapāo'o declared: "I have seen that Nāmakaokapāo'o is indeed a great man, and he has gone to Ko'olau, and I bear his name." They replied: "No, it is you indeed, thus we have heard, therefore you shall die by our hands, you shall not live." Nāmakaokapāo'o responded: "Let us all go down and fight." When they descended, Nāmakaokapāo'o violently overpowered them until all were dead, except one man who fled and reached 'Ama'u at Waikīkī. He reported the death of all their companions, leaving only him to deliver the news for 'Ama'u to hear.
</translation>

<commentary>
**Paragraph 13:**
• This passage demonstrates a classic confrontation scene in Hawaiian mo'olelo, with deep cultural undercurrents:
– Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o (lit. "the eyes of the pāo'o fish") asserts his ali'i status through name-bearing rights, a key Hawaiian concept called *inoa hō'ailona* (name as spiritual signature). His claim "I bear his name" (ʻo wau he inoa nona) reflects the Hawaiian belief that names carry the essence (*mana*) of their bearers (Footnote: Pukui notes in *'Ōlelo No'eau* that "I ka 'ōlelo nō ke ola, i ka 'ōlelo nō ka make" - "In speech is life, in speech is death" - showing the power of verbal declarations).
  
• The geographic markers hold symbolic weight:
– Ko'olau (windward side) vs. Waikīkī (leeward) creates an axis of power movement, common in mo'olelo to show shifting authority.
– 'Ama'u (a fern species) at Waikīkī may represent resilience (as ferns regenerate after fire), hinting at cyclical warfare.

• The battle scene reflects traditional Hawaiian combat protocols:
– The phrase "ho'i aku... i lalo e hakakā ai" follows the *kūkā pū* tradition where conflicts were resolved in designated neutral areas.
– The lone survivor as messenger mirrors the *kāhea* (call-and-response) protocol in war, where news must be ceremonially delivered (Footnote: Kamakau's *Ruling Chiefs of Hawaii* documents this practice during Kamehameha's wars).

• Allegorical interpretation:
– The eyes (maka) in Nāmakaokapāo'o's name may represent vigilance against threats, while pāo'o (a quick fish) symbolizes tactical retreats.
– The mass death scene parallels the volcanic land-building process of Ko'olau, where destruction creates new foundations - mirroring the hero's path of clearing obstacles for his destiny.

• Numerical symbolism:
– The "all except one" survivor pattern follows Hawaiian epic structures (as in *Kū-ali'i mo'olelo*) where a witness preserves knowledge, reflecting the *kilo* (observer) tradition in Hawaiian voyaging culture.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I know. Nāmakaokapāo'o is a really big guy. He went to Ko'olau. I'm named after him." The soldiers said, "No, it's you. That's what we heard. So, we're going to kill you. You won't survive." Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "Well, let's go down and fight." When they got down, Nāmakaokapāo'o went to work and killed them all except one man, who ran off and reached 'Ama'u in Waikīkī. He told him about the how they were all killed except for one runner to go and tell 'Ama'u about it.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
